answer_llm: The parameter count for a Conv2d layer is determined by the formula (3*3*3 +1) * 32, where 3 represents the size of the kernel, 3 represents the RGB channels, 1 is for the bias, and 32 is the number of filters. In the case of the Flatten layer, the number of "features" is calculated by multiplying the dimensions after convolutions and poolings, which is 7x7x128, resulting in 6272 vectors.
answer_orig:
Let’s say we define our Conv2d layer like this:
>> tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(32, (3,3), activation='relu', input_shape=(150, 150, 3))
It means our input image is RGB (3 channels, 150 by 150 pixels), kernel is 3x3 and number of filters (layer’s width) is 32.
If we check model.summary() we will get this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
conv2d (Conv2D)             (None, 148, 148, 32)      896
So where does 896 params come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> (3*3*3 +1) * 32
896
# 3x3 kernel, 3 channels RGB, +1 for bias, 32 filters
What about the number of “features” we get after the Flatten layer?
For our homework model.summary() for last MaxPooling2d and Flatten layers looked like this:
_________________________________________________________________
Layer (type)                Output Shape              Param #
=================================================================
max_pooling2d_3       (None, 7, 7, 128)         0
flatten (Flatten)           (None, 6272)              0
So where do 6272 vectors come from? It’s computed like this:
>>> 7*7*128
6272
# 7x7 “image shape” after several convolutions and poolings, 128 filters
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What determines the parameter count for a Conv2d layer?

answer_llm:
The output shape of a Conv2d layer shown in model.summary() is derived based on the kernel size, input shape, and number of filters. In the example provided:
- Input image is RGB (3 channels, 150 by 150 pixels)
- Kernel size is 3x3
- Number of filters is 32
The number of parameters (896) in this Conv2d layer is computed as:
(3*3*3 + 1) * 32
The number of "features" obtained after the Flatten layer is computed based on the output shape of the previous layer. In the example provided:
- Output shape after MaxPooling2d is (7, 7, 128)
The number of "features" after Flatten layer is calculated as:
7 * 7 * 128 = 6272
answer_orig:
Let’s say we define our Conv2d layer like this:
>> tf.keras.layers.Conv2D(32, (3,3), activation='relu', input_shape=(150, 150, 3))

=================================================================
conv2d (Conv2D)             (None, 148, 148, 32)      896
So where does 896 params come from? It’s computed like this:

896
# 3x3 kernel, 3 channels RGB, +1 for bias, 32 filters
What about the number of “features” we get after the Flatten layer?
For our homework model.summary() for last MaxPooling2d and Flatten layers looked like this:

=================================================================
max_pooling2d_3       (None, 7, 7, 128)         0

So where do 6272 vectors come from? It’s computed like this:

6272

Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm: The main difference between the Sequential and Functional Model API in Keras is that the Sequential Model API is easier to use as you can simply start with an empty model and add more layers in a sequential order. On the other hand, the Functional Model API is more advanced and involves chained calls of different entities like "inputs", "base", "vectors", and "outputs". This mode may be more suitable for tasks like Transfer Learning where you want to separate the "Base" model from the rest.
answer_orig:
It’s quite useful to understand that all types of models in the course are a plain stack of layers where each layer has exactly one input tensor and one output tensor (Sequential model TF page, Sequential class).
You can simply start from an “empty” model and add more and more layers in a sequential order.
This mode is called “Sequential Model API”  (easier)
In Alexey’s videos it is implemented as chained calls of different entities (“inputs”,“base”, “vectors”,  “outputs”) in a more advanced mode “Functional Model API”.
Maybe a more complicated way makes sense when you do Transfer Learning and want to separate “Base” model vs. rest, but in the HW you need to recreate the full model from scratch ⇒ I believe it is easier to work with a sequence of “similar” layers.
You can read more about it in this TF2 tutorial.
A really useful Sequential model example is shared in the Kaggle’s “Bee or Wasp” dataset folder with code: notebook
Added by Ivan Brigida
Fresh Run on Neural Nets
While correcting an error on neural net architecture, it is advised to do fresh run by restarting kernel, else the model learns on top of previous runs.
Added by Abhijit Chakraborty

answer_llm:
To fix out of memory errors in TensorFlow when using an Nvidia GPU, you can add the following code snippet at the beginning of your notebook:

```
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```

Additionally, you can also try setting memory growth for the GPU using the following code snippet:

```
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    pass
```
answer_orig:
I found this code snippet fixed my OOM errors, as I have an Nvidia GPU. Can't speak to OOM errors on CPU, though.
https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/config/experimental/set_memory_growth
```
physical_devices = tf.configlist_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0],True)
except:
# Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
pass
```

answer_llm:
Since the error message "Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized" can occur when trying to set memory growth for a TensorFlow GPU but running on a CPU, you can handle it by wrapping the code snippet in a try-except block. In the except block, you can simply pass to avoid any errors. Here's how you can do it:

```python
physical_devices = tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU')
try:
    tf.config.experimental.set_memory_growth(physical_devices[0], True)
except:
    # Invalid device or cannot modify virtual devices once initialized.
    pass
```

answer_llm: To speed up model training on Google Colab with a T4 GPU, you can specify the number of workers/threads in the fit function. Changing the workers variable to a higher value, like 2560, can help improve the training speed. This adjustment was particularly useful for the T4 GPU in Google Colab, as the default value for workers is 1.
answer_orig:
When training the models, in the fit function, you can specify the number of workers/threads.
The number of threads apparently also works for GPUs, and came very handy in google colab for the T4 GPU, since it was very very slow, and workers default value is 1.
I changed the workers variable to 2560, following this thread in stackoverflow. I am using the free T4 GPU.  (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/68208398/how-to-find-the-number-of-cores-in-google-colabs-gpu)
Added by Ibai Irastorza

answer_llm: ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code in Keras because tf.keras.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator is deprecated. It is suggested to use tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory and transform the output tf.data.Dataset with preprocessing layers instead.
answer_orig:
From the keras documentation:
Deprecated: tf.keras.preprocessing.image.ImageDataGenerator is not recommended for new code. Prefer loading images with tf.keras.utils.image_dataset_from_directory and transforming the output tf.data.Dataset with preprocessing layers. For more information, see the tutorials for loading images and augmenting images, as well as the preprocessing layer guide.
Hrithik Kumar Advani

answer_llm: When the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} returns nothing, it means that the variable REMOTE_URI has not been set in the current session. To set the REMOTE_URI variable and assign your URI address to it, you can use the command: export REMOTE_URI=your_URI_address. For example: export REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images. After setting the variable, you can then use the command echo $REMOTE_URI to see the URI address. Just make sure to replace "your_URI_address" with your actual URI address.
answer_orig:
Solution description
In the unit 9.6, Alexey ran the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} which turned the URI address in the terminal. There workaround is to set a local variable (REMOTE_URI) and assign your URI address in the terminal and use it to login the registry, for instance, REMOTE_URI=2278222782.dkr.ecr.ap-south-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images (fake address). One caveat is that you will lose this variable once the session is terminated.
I also had the same problem on Ubuntu terminal. I executed the following two commands:
$ export REMOTE_URI=1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
$ echo $REMOTE_URI
111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
Note: 1. no curly brackets (e.g. echo ${REMOTE_URI}) needed unlike in video 9.6,
2. Replace REMOTE_URI with your URI
(Bhaskar Sarma)
question: What does it mean when the command echo ${REMOTE_URI} returns nothing?

answer_llm:
To set the REMOTE_URI variable to your URI address, you can execute the following commands in your terminal:
$ export REMOTE_URI=1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001
$ echo $REMOTE_URI
Make sure to replace "1111111111.dkr.ecr.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images:clothing-model-xception-v4-001" with your actual URI address. Note that there is no need for curly brackets when using echo unlike in video 9.6.

answer_llm: The updated command to fetch the password from aws-cli when the original returns an invalid choice error is: aws ecr get-login-password
answer_orig:
The command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email returns an invalid choice error:
The solution is to use the following command instead:  aws ecr get-login-password
Could simplify the login process with, just replace the <ACCOUNT_NUMBER> and <REGION> with your values:
export PASSWORD=`aws ecr get-login-password`
docker login -u AWS -p $PASSWORD <ACCOUNT_NUMBER>.dkr.ecr.<REGION>.amazonaws.com/clothing-tflite-images
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm: The ERROR [internal] load metadata for public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.8 might be caused when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
answer_orig:
This error is produced sometimes when building your docker image from the Amazon python base image.
Solution description: The following could solve the problem.
Update your docker desktop if you haven’t done so.
Or restart docker desktop and terminal and then build the image all over again.
Or if all else fails, first run the following command: DOCKER_BUILDKIT=0  docker build .  then build your image.
(optional) Added by Odimegwu David

answer_llm: If you get the error message 'type InterpreterWrapper is already registered', the solution is to restart the kernel and import only `tflite_runtime.interpreter` as `tflite`. Avoid importing both `tensorflow` and `tflite_runtime.interpreter` in the same notebook.
answer_orig:
When I run   import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite , I get an error message says “ImportError: generic_type: type "InterpreterWrapper" is already registered!”
Solution description
This error occurs when you import both tensorflow  and tflite_runtime.interpreter  “import tensorflow as tf” and “import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite” in the same notebook.  To fix the issue, restart the kernel and import only tflite_runtime.interpreter " import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite".

got this Using default tag: latest
[2022-11-24T06:48:47.360149000Z][docker-credential-desktop][W] Windows version might not be up-to-date: The system cannot find the file specified.

.

You need to make sure that Docker is not stopped by a third-party program.

answer_llm: The lambda function passes local tests but fails on a running docker instance because the individual estimation values returned as numpy float32 values need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become "serializable."
answer_orig:
Problem:
While passing local testing of the lambda function without issues, trying to test the same input with a running docker instance results in an error message like
{‘errorMessage’: ‘Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable’, ‘errorType’: ‘Runtime.MarshalError’, ‘requestId’: ‘f155492c-9af2-4d04-b5a4-639548b7c7ac’, ‘stackTrace’: []}
This happens when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). They need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become “serializable”.
Solution:
In my particular case, I set up the dino vs dragon model in such a way as to return a label + predicted probability for each class as follows (below is a two-line extract of function predict() in the lambda_function.py):
preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], \
1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]
In which case the above described solution will look like this:
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Why does my lambda function pass local tests but fail on a running docker instance?

answer_llm: The 'Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable' error in your model occurs when the model returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). These values need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become "serializable" and avoid the error.

float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: What changes need to be made to the dino vs dragon model to avoid the JSON serialization issue?

answer_llm: To resolve lambda function errors in serverless deep learning regarding the "Unable to import module 'lambda_function': No module named 'tensorflow'" issue, refer to Section 9: Serverless Deep Learning. Specifically, ensure that all codes in the test.py file don't have any dependencies with the tensorflow library. You may need to change the import statement from "import tensorflow.lite as tflite" to "import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite." This adjustment should help resolve the error related to importing the tensorflow module.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While passing local testing of the lambda function without issues, trying to test the same input with a running docker instance results in an error message like
{‘errorMessage’: ‘Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable’, ‘errorType’: ‘Runtime.MarshalError’, ‘requestId’: ‘f155492c-9af2-4d04-b5a4-639548b7c7ac’, ‘stackTrace’: []}
This happens when a model (in this case the dino vs dragon model) returns individual estimation values as numpy float32 values (arrays). They need to be converted individually to base-Python floats in order to become “serializable”.
Solution:
In my particular case, I set up the dino vs dragon model in such a way as to return a label + predicted probability for each class as follows (below is a two-line extract of function predict() in the lambda_function.py):
preds = [interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0], \
1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]]
In which case the above described solution will look like this:
preds = [float(interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0]), \
float(1-interpreter.get_tensor(output_index)[0][0])]
The rest can be made work by following the chapter 9 (and/or chapter 5!) lecture videos step by step.
Added by Konrad Muehlberg
question: Which chapters and videos should I refer to for resolving lambda function errors in serverless deep learning?

answer_llm: The error when running the `interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x)` command is caused by the fact that `X` is an integer, but a float is expected. To resolve this error, you need to convert `X` to float32 before using `set_tensor`.
answer_orig:
I had this error when running the command line : interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x) that can be seen in the video 9.3 around 12 minutes.
ValueError: Cannot set tensor: Got value of type UINT8 but expected type FLOAT32 for input 0, name: serving_default_conv2d_input:0
This is because the X is an int but a float is expected.
Solution:
I found this solution from this question here https://stackoverflow.com/questions/76102508/valueerror-cannot-set-tensor-got-value-of-type-float64-but-expected-type-float :
# Need to convert to float32 before set_tensor
X = np.float32(X)
Then, it works. I work with tensorflow 2.15.0, maybe the fact that this version is more recent involves this change ?
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard
question: What causes the error when running the interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, x) command?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error with the line "interpreter.set_tensor(input_index, X", you need to convert the variable X to float32 before using it in the set_tensor function. You can do this by adding the following code:
X = np.float32(X)
This will ensure that a float is being used instead of an int, which is expected by the set_tensor function.

answer_llm:
To check the size of a file using the Powershell terminal, you can use the following command lines:
$File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
$FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
Now you can check the size of your file, for example in MB:
Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
answer_orig:
To check your file size using the powershell terminal, you can do the following command lines:
$File = Get-Item -Path path_to_file
$FileSize = (Get-Item -Path $FilePath).Length
Now you can check the size of your file, for example in MB:
Write-host "MB":($FileSize/1MB)
Source: https://www.sharepointdiary.com/2020/10/powershell-get-file-size.html#:~:text=To%20get%20the%20size%20of,the%20file%2C%20including%20its%20size.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard

answer_llm:
To create and push a docker image for AWS Lambda, you can follow these steps:
1. Build your Docker image based on the AWS Lambda base image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10).
2. Test your Docker image locally using AWS RIE for deployment.
3. Use the "docker run" command with specific ports to start the image container.
4. Access the endpoint locally at localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations for testing.
5. Post an event to the endpoint using a curl command similar to the examples provided in the context.
6. If you encounter a JSON serialization error, convert the response in your lambda_handler() function to a string using str(result).
7. This process allows you to create and test a docker image for AWS Lambda locally before pushing it to Lambda for deployment.
answer_orig:
The docker image for aws lambda can be created and pushed to aws ecr and the same can be exposed as a REST API through APIGatewayService in a single go using AWS Serverless Framework. Refer the below article for a detailed walkthrough.
https://medium.com/hoonio/deploy-containerized-serverless-flask-to-aws-lambda-c0eb87c1404d
Added by Sumeet Lalla

answer_llm: To resolve the pip install error when building a Docker image in Section 9.5 on an M1 Mac, you should use the link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl. If that does not work, you can try running the code in a PC or Ubuntu OS. Another solution is to use the command "docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model" for building the Docker image.
answer_orig:
Problem:
While trying to build docker image in Section 9.5 with the command:
docker build -t clothing-model .
It throws a pip install error for the tflite runtime whl
ERROR: failed to solve: process "/bin/sh -c pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/blob/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl" did not complete successfully: exit code: 1
Try to use this link: https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.14.0-cp310-cp310-linux_x86_64.whl
If the link above does not work:
The problem is because of the arm architecture of the M1. You will need to run the code on a PC or Ubuntu OS.
Or try the code bellow.
Added by Dashel Ruiz Perez
Solution:
To build the Docker image, use the command:
docker build --platform linux/amd64 -t clothing-model .
To run the built image, use the command:
docker run -it --rm -p 8080:8080 --platform linux/amd64 clothing-model:latest
Added by Daniel Egbo

answer_llm:
If the command 'docker build -t clothing-model .' throws a tflite runtime whl error on an M1 Mac, the solution is to use the following command to build the Docker image instead:

answer_llm: If you encounter a 'Missing Authentication Token' error while testing API Gateway in section 9.7, you need to get the deployed API URL for the specific path you are invoking. For example, the URL should look something like this: https://<random string>.execute-api.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/test/predict.
answer_orig:
Problem: Trying to test API gateway in 9.7 - API Gateway: Exposing the Lambda Function, running: $ python test.py
With error message:
{'message': 'Missing Authentication Token'}
Solution:
Need to get the deployed API URL for the specific path you are invoking. Example:
https://<random string>.execute-api.us-east-2.amazonaws.com/test/predict
Added by Andrew Katoch

answer_llm: If you encounter the error 'Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime', the issue may be due to compatibility with Python 3.10. To resolve this, try installing Python 3.9, which should allow you to install tflite_runtime without any problems. Alternatively, you can check for available tflite_runtime versions that match your setup at the provided links, and install them using the appropriate pip command. If all else fails, consider using the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development and use Docker for testing Lambda.
answer_orig:
Problem: When trying to install tflite_runtime with
!pip install --extra-index-url https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/ tflite_runtime
one gets an error message above.
Solution:
fflite_runtime is only available for the os-python version combinations that can be found here: https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
your combination must be missing here
you can see if any of these work for you https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
and install the needed one using pip
eg
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
as it is done in the lectures code:
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/mlbookcamp-code/blob/master/course-zoomcamp/09-serverless/code/Dockerfile#L4
Alternatively, use a virtual machine (with VM VirtualBox, for example) with a Linux system. The other way is to run a code at a virtual machine within cloud service, for example you can use Vertex AI Workbench at GCP (notebooks and terminals are provided there, so all tasks may be performed).

answer_llm:
To save a Docker image to your local machine, you can use the following command:
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
This will export the Docker image to a tar format file on your local machine.
answer_orig:
The docker image can be saved/exported to tar format in local machine using the below command:
docker image save <image-name> -o <name-of-tar-file.tar>
The individual layers of the docker image for the filesystem content can be viewed by extracting the layer.tar present in the <name-of-tar-file.tar> created from above.
Sumeet Lalla

answer_llm: ANSWER: The command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email returns an invalid choice error. You should use the following command instead: aws ecr get-login-password.
answer_orig: see here
question: What should I do if the command aws ecr get-login --no-include-email gives an invalid choice error?

answer_llm: To resolve the "aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice" error in section 9, you should use the following command instead: aws ecr get-login-password. Make sure to replace <ACCOUNT_NUMBER> and <REGION> with your specific values. This will simplify the login process.
answer_orig: see here
question: How can I resolve the aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice error in section 9?

answer_llm:
To find help for the "aws ecr get-login --no-include-email" command error, you can refer to the AWS documentation provided at: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html.
Additionally, you can run the following command to resolve the issue:
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com

Alternatively, if you have a default region configured, you can run this command:
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
answer_orig: see here

answer_llm:
To sign in to the AWS Console for Week 9: Serverless, you need to follow these steps:
1. Log in to the AWS Console.
2. Navigate to IAM by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner and selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section.
3. Create a new policy by selecting "Policies" in the left navigation pane and clicking on "Create policy."
4. Select the service and actions then click on "Review policy."
5. Provide a name and description for the policy.
6. Click on "Create policy."
answer_orig:
Sign in to the AWS Console: Log in to the AWS Console.
Navigate to IAM: Go to the IAM service by clicking on "Services" in the top left corner and selecting "IAM" under the "Security, Identity, & Compliance" section.
Create a new policy: In the left navigation pane, select "Policies" and click on "Create policy."
Select the service and actions:
Click on "JSON" and copy and paste the JSON policy you provided earlier for the specific ECR actions.
Review and create the policy:
Click on "Review policy."
Provide a name and description for the policy.
Click on "Create policy."
JSON policy:
{
"Version": "2012-10-17",
"Statement": [
{
"Sid": "VisualEditor0",
"Effect": "Allow",
"Action": [
"ecr:CreateRepository",
"ecr:GetAuthorizationToken",
"ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability",
"ecr:BatchGetImage",
"ecr:InitiateLayerUpload",
"ecr:UploadLayerPart",
"ecr:CompleteLayerUpload",
"ecr:PutImage"
],
"Resource": "*"
}
]
}
Added by: Daniel Muñoz-Viveros
ERROR: failed to solve: public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10: error getting credentials - err: exec: "docker-credential-desktop.exe": executable file not found in $PATH, out: ``

Solved: Delete the file ~/.docker/config.json
Yishan Zhan

Create a new policy: In the left navigation pane, select "Policies" and click on "Create policy."
Select the service and actions:
Click on "JSON" and copy and paste the JSON policy you provided earlier for the specific ECR actions.
Review and create the policy:
Click on "Review policy."
Provide a name and description for the policy.
Click on "Create policy."
JSON policy:
{
"Version": "2012-10-17",
"Statement": [
{
"Sid": "VisualEditor0",
"Effect": "Allow",
"Action": [
"ecr:CreateRepository",
"ecr:GetAuthorizationToken",
"ecr:BatchCheckLayerAvailability",
"ecr:BatchGetImage",
"ecr:InitiateLayerUpload",
"ecr:UploadLayerPart",
"ecr:CompleteLayerUpload",
"ecr:PutImage"
],
"Resource": "*"
}
]
}

answer_llm: To test AWS Lambda with Docker locally, you can use AWS RIE(runtime interface emulator). You can run the Docker image as a container and start an endpoint locally by using certain ports for "docker run" command. For testing, you can post an event to the endpoint using a curl command. Use a specific localhost link for testing and make sure to turn your response at lambda_handler() to a string if you encounter any errors.
answer_orig:
This deployment setup can be tested locally using AWS RIE (runtime interface emulator).
Basically, if your Docker image was built upon base AWS Lambda image (FROM public.ecr.aws/lambda/python:3.10) - just use certain ports for “docker run” and a certain “localhost link” for testing:
docker run -it --rm -p 9000:8080 name
This command runs the image as a container and starts up an endpoint locally at:
localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations
Post an event to the following endpoint using a curl command:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{}'
Examples of curl testing:
* windows testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d "{\"url\": \"https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg\"}"
* unix testing:
curl -XPOST "http://localhost:9000/2015-03-31/functions/function/invocations" -d '{"url": "https://habrastorage.org/webt/rt/d9/dh/rtd9dhsmhwrdezeldzoqgijdg8a.jpeg"}'
If during testing you encounter an error like this:
# {"errorMessage": "Unable to marshal response: Object of type float32 is not JSON serializable", "errorType": "Runtime.MarshalError", "requestId": "7ea5d17a-e0a2-48d5-b747-a16fc530ed10", "stackTrace": []}
just turn your response at lambda_handler() to string - str(result).
Added by Andrii Larkin
question: What setup is needed to test AWS Lambda with Docker locally?

answer_llm: Based on the context provided, you are getting the error 'Unable to import module 'lambda_function': No module named 'tensorflow' when running python test.py because there are dependencies with the tensorflow library in the code. Specifically, one common reason for this error is importing tflite from tensorflow. To resolve this, you should change the import statement from import tensorflow.lite as tflite to import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite in your code.
answer_orig:
Make sure all codes in test.py dont have any dependencies with tensorflow library. One of most common reason that lead the this error is tflite still imported from tensorflow. Change import tensorflow.lite as tflite to import tflite_runtime.interpreter as tflite
Added by Ryan Pramana

- Check the available versions at https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/ and make sure your combination is listed.
- If your combination is not listed, you can try the options at https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite and install the needed version using pip.
- Alternatively, you can use a virtual machine with a Linux system, or run the code on a virtual machine within a cloud service like Vertex AI Workbench at GCP.
- If you are working with Python 3.10, consider installing Python 3.9 to make tflite_runtime work without issues.
- If you encounter errors related to the Python version, ensure you are using the correct wheel version for your Python setup.

answer_llm:
The prerequisites for installing TensorFlow with CUDA support in WSL2 as per the provided resources are:

1. Install Nvidia drivers: https://www.nvidia.com/download/index.aspx
2. Install CUDA toolkit 11.x.x from https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-toolkit-archive
3. Install cuDNN from https://developer.nvidia.com/rdp/cudnn-download
4. Follow step 4 in the Tensorflow installation guide to install CUDA by environment: https://www.tensorflow.org/install/pip#linux_1
5. Run: echo ‘export XLA_FLAGS=--xla_gpu_cuda_data_dir=$CONDA_PREFIX/lib/> $CONDA_PREFIX/etc/conda/activate.d/env_vars.sh

Make sure to have the right hardware before proceeding with the installation.
answer_orig:
Running a CNN on your CPU can take a long time and once you’ve run out of free time on some cloud providers, it’s time to pay up. Both can be tackled by installing tensorflow with CUDA support on your local machine if you have the right hardware.
I was able to get it working by using the following resources:
CUDA on WSL :: CUDA Toolkit Documentation (nvidia.com)
Install TensorFlow with pip
Start Locally | PyTorch
I included the link to PyTorch so that you can get that one installed and working too while everything is fresh on your mind. Just select your options, and for Computer Platform, I chose CUDA 11.7 and it worked for me.
Added by Martin Uribe

answer_llm:
If you are getting "Allocator ran out of memory errors" when running TensorFlow on your machine, you can try adding the following code at the beginning of your notebook:
```
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
```
This may help resolve the issue.
answer_orig:
If you are running tensorflow on your own machine and you start getting the following errors:
Allocator (GPU_0_bfc) ran out of memory trying to allocate 6.88GiB with freed_by_count=0. The caller indicates that this is not a failure, but this may mean that there could be performance gains if more memory were available.
Try adding this code in a cell at the beginning of your notebook:
config = tf.compat.v1.ConfigProto()
config.gpu_options.allow_growth = True
session = tf.compat.v1.Session(config=config)
After doing this most of my issues went away. I say most because there was one instance when I still got the error once more, but only during one epoch. I ran the code again, right after it finished, and I never saw the error again.
Added by Martin Uribe
question: What should I do if I get Allocator ran out of memory errors while running TensorFlow on my machine?

answer_llm:
The error that might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py is:
`TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.` This error indicates that the generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0 due to a problem with recent versions of protobuf. To resolve this issue, you can either downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower, or set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python, although this will result in slower parsing.
answer_orig:
In session 10.3, when creating the virtual environment with pipenv and trying to run the script gateway.py, you might get this error:
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
More information: https://developers.google.com/protocol-buffers/docs/news/2022-05-06#python-updates
This will happen if your version of protobuf is one of the newer ones. As a workaround, you can fix the protobuf version to an older one. In my case I got around the issue by creating the environment with:
pipenv install --python 3.9.13 requests grpcio==1.42.0 flask gunicorn \
keras-image-helper tensorflow-protobuf==2.7.0 protobuf==3.19.6
Added by Ángel de Vicente
question: What error might occur when creating the virtual environment in session 10.3 with pipenv and running gateway.py?

answer_llm: To resolve the TypeError issue caused by the recent version of protobuf in session 10.3, you can follow the solution provided in the context. Downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.1 by running the command: `pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1`. This should fix the problem you are facing.

answer_llm: If WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon, the solution is to enable additional distros in Docker Desktop settings. Just go to Docker Desktop settings, click on resources, then WSL Integration, and enable additional distros.
answer_orig:
Due to the uncertainties associated with machines, sometimes you can get the error message like this when you try to run a docker command:
”Cannot connect to the Docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?”
Solution: The solution is simple. The Docker Desktop might no longer be connecting to the WSL Linux distro. What you need to do is go to your Docker Desktop setting and then click on resources. Under resources, click on WSL Integration. You will get a tab like the image below:
Just enable additional distros. That’s all. Even if the additional distro is the same as the default WSL distro.
Odimegwu David
question: What should I do if WSL cannot connect to the Docker daemon?

answer_llm:
To resolve the error 'Cannot connect to the docker daemon at unix:///var/run/docker.sock. Is the docker daemon running?', you can follow different solutions based on your operating system:
1. If you are using WSL:
   - Re-install Docker: Remove the docker installation from WSL and install Docker Desktop on your host machine (Windows).

2. If you are using Linux:
   - Start the docker daemon with either of these commands:
     - sudo dockerd
     - sudo service docker start

3. If you are experiencing issues with Docker Desktop connecting to WSL Linux distro:
   - Go to Docker Desktop settings and click on resources.
   - Under resources, click on WSL Integration.
   - Enable additional distros.

4. If you are trying to run a docker command in Windows and encounter an error:
   - Make sure Docker is not stopped by a third-party program.

5. If you are facing issues with Python versions in Windows when running the docker file:
   - Add the Python311 installation folder to the PATH.
   - Restart the system and run the docker file again.

answer_llm:
If the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server, you can run the following command to hopefully fix the issue:
kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml, which embeds the - --kubelet-insecure-tls option.
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela
question: What should be done if the HPA instance doesn't work correctly even after installing the latest Metrics Server?

answer_llm:
To edit the metrics-server deployment and fix the HPA issue, you can run the command:
kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
Search for the line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle: - --kubelet-insecure-tls
Save the changes and run:
kubectl get hpa
answer_orig:
In case the HPA instance does not run correctly even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
>>kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
And the targets still appear as <unknown>
Run >>kubectl edit deploy -n kube-system metrics-server
And search for this line:
args:
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Add this line in the middle:  - --kubelet-insecure-tls
So that it stays like this:
args:
- --kubelet-insecure-tls
- --kubelet-preferred-address-types=InternalIP,ExternalIP,Hostname
Save and run again >>kubectl get hpa
Added by Marilina Orihuela

question: What command do we run after editing the metrics-server to check the HPA status again?

answer_llm:
ANSWER: If the HPA instance does not run even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server, you can run the following command:
kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Peco602/ml-zoomcamp/main/10-kubernetes/kube-config/metrics-server-deployment.yaml
This file already embeds the - --kubelet-insecure-tls option, which should help resolve the issue.
answer_orig:

Run the following command:

Which uses a metrics server deployment file already embedding the - --kubelet-insecure-tls option.
Added by Giovanni Pecoraro
question: What should I do if the HPA instance does not run even after installing the latest version of Metrics Server?

answer_llm:
To fix the targets appearing as <unknown> in your HPA instance, you can follow these steps:
- Delete the HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
- Apply the latest version of Metrics Server from the components.yaml manifest with:
  kubectl apply -f https://github.com/kubernetes-sigs/metrics-server/releases/latest/download/components.yaml
- Create the HPA again
This should solve the issue with the targets appearing as <unknown> in your HPA instance.

answer_llm: To resolve the 'Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied' error when installing libraries in Windows, you can use the `--user` option when running the `pip install` command. For example, you can run `pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0` to install the libraries in Windows machine without permission issues.
answer_orig:
When I run pip install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0 to install the libraries in windows machine,  I was getting the below error :
ERROR: Could not install packages due to an OSError: [WinError 5] Access is denied: 'C:\\Users\\Asia\\anaconda3\\Lib\\site-packages\\google\\protobuf\\internal\\_api_implementation.cp39-win_amd64.pyd'
Consider using the `--user` option or check the permissions.
Solution description :
I was able to install the libraries using below command:
pip --user install grpcio==1.42.0 tensorflow-serving-api==2.7.0
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: The error that occurs when running gateway.py after modifying the code in video 10.3 is "TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly."
answer_orig:
Problem description
I was getting the below error message when I run gateway.py after modifying the code & creating virtual environment in  video 10.3 :
File "C:\Users\Asia\Data_Science_Code\Zoompcamp\Kubernetes\gat.py", line 9, in <module>
from tensorflow_serving.apis import predict_pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow_serving\apis\predict_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import resource_handle_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_resource__handle__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\resource_handle_pb2.py", line 14, in <module>
from tensorflow.core.framework import tensor_shape_pb2 as tensorflow_dot_core_dot_framework_dot_tensor__shape__pb2
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\core\framework\tensor_shape_pb2.py", line 36, in <module>
_descriptor.FieldDescriptor(
File "C:\Users\Asia\.virtualenvs\Kubernetes-Ge6Ts1D5\lib\site-packages\google\protobuf\descriptor.py", line 560, in __new__
_message.Message._CheckCalledFromGeneratedFile()
TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly.
If this call came from a _pb2.py file, your generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0.
If you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, some other possible workarounds are:
1. Downgrade the protobuf package to 3.20.x or lower.
2. Set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).
Solution description:
Issue has been resolved by downgrading protobuf to version 3.20.1.
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1
Asia Saeed
question: What error occurs when running gateway.py after modifying the code in video 10.3?

answer_llm: The `TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly` error occurs when the generated code is out of date and must be regenerated with protoc >= 3.19.0. To fix this issue, you can downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower. Alternatively, you can set `PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python`, but this will result in slower performance due to pure-Python parsing.

question: What causes the TypeError: Descriptors cannot not be created directly?

answer_llm:
To resolve the issue of your generated protobuf code being out of date and causing the TypeError "Descriptors cannot not be created directly," you can downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.1. You can do this by running the following command:
pipenv install protobuf==3.20.1

Additionally, if you cannot immediately regenerate your protos, you can also downgrade the protobuf package to version 3.20.x or lower, or set PROTOCOL_BUFFERS_PYTHON_IMPLEMENTATION=python (but this will use pure-Python parsing and will be much slower).

answer_llm: To install kubectl easily on Windows, you can follow this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff. First, download kubectl with curl using the command lines provided here: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows. Then, follow the tutorial to copy the exe file to a specific folder on the C drive and add this folder path to the PATH in your environment variables. This same method can be used to install Kind on Windows as well.
answer_orig:
To install kubectl on windows using the terminal in vscode (powershell), I followed this tutorial: https://medium.com/@ggauravsigra/install-kubectl-on-windows-af77da2e6fff
I first downloaded kubectl with curl, with these command lines: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/tools/install-kubectl-windows/#install-kubectl-binary-with-curl-on-windows
At step 3, I followed the tutorial with the copy of the exe file in a specific folder on C drive.
Then I added this folder path to PATH in my environment variables.
Kind can be installed the same way with the curl command on windows, by specifying a folder that will be added to the path environment variable.
Added by Mélanie Fouesnard
question: How can I install kubectl easily on Windows?

answer_llm: To install Kind using choco, you need to first install choco library through Powershell. After that, launch a Powershell terminal with administrator privilege. Once choco library is installed, you can proceed with installing Kind via choco.
answer_orig:
First you need to launch a powershell terminal with administrator privilege.
For this we need to install choco library first through the following syntax in powershell:
Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Scope Process -Force; [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol = [System.Net.ServicePointManager]::SecurityProtocol -bor 3072; iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://chocolatey.org/install.ps1'))
Krishna Anand

answer_llm:
To resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl, you can try the following steps:

1. Run the command:
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster

2. After completing the above steps, try running the kubectl command again:
kubectl get service

This should resolve the connection issue you are facing.
answer_orig:
I ran into an issue where kubectl wasn't working.
I kept getting the following error:
kubectl get service
The connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused - did you specify the right host or port?
I searched online for a resolution, but everyone kept talking about creating an environment variable and creating some admin.config file in my home directory.
All hogwash.
The solution to my problem was to just start over.
kind delete cluster
rm -rf ~/.kube
kind create cluster
Now when I try the same command again:
kubectl get service
NAME         TYPE        CLUSTER-IP   EXTERNAL-IP   PORT(S)   AGE
kubernetes   ClusterIP   10.96.0.1    <none>        443/TCP   53s
Added by Martin Uribe
question: How can I resolve the 'connection to the server localhost:8080 was refused' issue with kubectl?

answer_llm: Martin Uribe fixed the kubectl server connection issue by deleting the existing cluster, removing the ~/.kube directory, and then creating a new cluster using the command "kind create cluster".

answer_llm: To solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images, you can first remove the unnecessary docker images using the command `docker rmi` to free up space. However, deleting docker images does not actually free up space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run `docker system prune` to reclaim the space on your system.
answer_orig:
Problem description
Due to experimenting back and forth so much without care for storage, I just ran out of it on my 30-GB AWS instance.
My first reflex was to remove some zoomcamp directories, but of course those are mostly code so it didn’t help much.
Solution description
> docker images
revealed that I had over 20 GBs worth of superseded / duplicate models lying around, so I proceeded to > docker rmi
a bunch of those — but to no avail!
It turns out that deleting docker images does not actually free up any space as you might expect. After removing images, you also need to run
> docker system prune
See also: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36799718/why-removing-docker-containers-and-images-does-not-free-up-storage-space-on-wind
Added by Konrad Mühlberg
question: How can I solve the issue of running out of storage after building many docker images?

answer_llm: Removing the zoomcamp directories didn't help in freeing up space because those directories mostly contain code, not large files like docker images. The real issue was the large amount of superseded/duplicate docker images taking up space, which required running "docker system prune" after removing the images to free up space.

answer_llm: CPU values in Kubernetes deployment.yaml have suffix 'm' because in Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
answer_orig:
In Kubernetes resource specifications, such as CPU requests and limits, the "m" stands for milliCPU, which is a unit of computing power. It represents one thousandth of a CPU core.
cpu: "100m" means the container is requesting 100 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.1 CPU core.
cpu: "500m" means the container has a CPU limit of 500 milliCPUs, which is equivalent to 0.5 CPU core.
These values are specified in milliCPUs to allow fine-grained control over CPU resources. It allows you to express CPU requirements and limits in a more granular way, especially in scenarios where your application might not need a full CPU core.
Added by Andrii Larkin

answer_llm: To fix the issue of a kind cluster not finding any nodes after loading a Docker image, you should specify the cluster name with the -n flag. Instead of just running `kind load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001`, run `kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001`.
answer_orig:
Problem: Failing to load docker-image to cluster (when you’ved named a cluster)
kind load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
ERROR: no nodes found for cluster "kind"
Solution: Specify cluster name with -n
kind -n clothing-model load docker-image zoomcamp-10-model:xception-v4-001
Andrew Katoch
question: What should I do if my kind cluster can't find any nodes after loading a Docker image?

answer_llm: If 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command on Windows, the solution is to rename the executable file from kind-windows-amd64.exe to kind.exe. Put this file in a specific folder and add it to the PATH.
answer_orig:
Problem: I download kind from the next command:
curl.exe -Lo kind-windows-amd64.exe https://kind.sigs.k8s.io/dl/v0.17.0/kind-windows-amd64
When I try
kind --version
I get: 'kind' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file
Solution: The default name of executable is kind-windows-amd64.exe, so that you have to rename this file to  kind.exe. Put this file in specific folder, and add it to PATH
Alejandro Aponte

question: What is the solution when 'kind' is not operable after executing kind --version on Windows?

answer_llm:
To make 'kind' executable once it's downloaded on a Windows machine, you need to follow these steps:
1. After downloading kind using the curl command, rename the file from 'kind-windows-amd64.exe' to 'kind.exe'.
2. Place the renamed 'kind.exe' file in a specific folder.
3. Add this folder path to the PATH environment variable on your Windows machine.

Solution: The default name of executable is kind-windows-amd64.exe, so that you have to rename this file to  kind.exe. Put this file in specific folder, and add it to PATH

answer_llm:
Solution:
The error related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask is due to using an old version of Werkzeug (2.2.2) with a new version of Flask (2.2.2). To resolve this issue, you can pin the version of Flask to an older version by running the command: pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
answer_orig:
Problem Description:
In video 10.3, when I was testing a flask service, I got the above error. I ran docker run .. in one terminal. When in second terminal I run python gateway.py, I get the above error.
Solution: This error has something to do with versions of Flask and Werkzeug. I got the same error, if I just import flask with from flask import Flask.
By running pip freeze > requirements.txt,I found that their versions are Flask==2.2.2 and Werkzeug==2.2.2. This error appears while using an old version of werkzeug (2.2.2) with new version of flask (2.2.2). I solved it by pinning version of Flask into an older version with pipenv install Flask==2.1.3.
Added by Bhaskar Sarma
question: What solution can you offer for the TypeError related to 'unbound_message' when importing Flask?

answer_llm: You should use the command `aws ecr get-login-password` instead of `aws ecr get-login --no-include-email` to get the password from aws-cli. This will resolve the invalid choice error you are facing.
answer_orig:
As per AWS documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html
You need to do: (change the fields in red)
aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com
Alternatively you can run the following command without changing anything given you have a default region configured
aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"
Added by Humberto Rodriguez
question: What should I do when I get 'aws: error: argument operation: Invalid choice' while using 'aws ecr get-login --no-include-email'?

answer_llm: You can find the AWS documentation related to AWS ECR login issues at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECR/latest/userguide/docker-push-ecr-image.html. The recommended command is `aws ecr get-login-password --region region | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin aws_account_id.dkr.ecr.region.amazonaws.com` or you can run `aws ecr get-login-password --region $(aws configure get region) | docker login --username AWS --password-stdin "$(aws sts get-caller-identity --query "Account" --output text).dkr.ecr.$(aws configure get region).amazonaws.com"` if you have a default region configured.

answer_llm: The solution for the TensorFlow Serving error on Apple M1 Mac is to use the command `docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest` and then run it with `docker run -it --rm -p 8500:8500 -v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 -e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64`. More information can be found on the GitHub page: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm.
answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
It outputs the error:
Error:
Status: Downloaded newer image for tensorflow/serving:2.7.0
[libprotobuf FATAL external/com_google_protobuf/src/google/protobuf/generated_message_reflection.cc:2345] CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution
docker pull emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest
docker run -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
emacski/tensorflow-serving:latest-linux_arm64
See more here: https://github.com/emacski/tensorflow-serving-arm
Added by Daniel Egbo

answer_orig:
While trying to run the docker code on M1:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \

terminate called after throwing an instance of 'google::protobuf::FatalException'
what():  CHECK failed: file != nullptr:
qemu: uncaught target signal 6 (Aborted) - core dumped
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     8 Aborted                 tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution

-p 8500:8500 \

question: Who provided the solution for the TensorFlow Serving issue on Apple M1 Mac?

answer_llm: If you are facing an Illegal instruction error when running tensorflow/serving image on Mac M2 Apple Silicon (potentially on M1 as well), the solution is to use the `bitnami/tensorflow-serving` base image instead of `tensorflow/serving`. Launch it using either the `docker run` command or a `docker-compose.yaml` file.
answer_orig:
Similar to the one above but with a different solution the main reason is that emacski doesn’t seem to maintain the repo any more, the latest image is from 2 years ago at the time of writing (December 2023)
Problem:
While trying to run the docker code on Mac M2 apple silicon:
docker run --platform linux/amd64 -it --rm \
-p 8500:8500 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/models/clothing-model/1 \
-e MODEL_NAME="clothing-model" \
tensorflow/serving
You get an error:
/usr/bin/tf_serving_entrypoint.sh: line 3:     7 Illegal instruction     tensorflow_model_server --port=8500 --rest_api_port=8501 --model_name=${MODEL_NAME} --model_base_path=${MODEL_BASE_PATH}/${MODEL_NAME} "$@"
Solution:
Use bitnami/tensorflow-serving base image
Launch it either using docker run
docker run -d \
--name tf_serving \
-p 8500:8500 \
-p 8501:8501 \
-v $(pwd)/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1 \
-e TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model \
bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
Or the following docker-compose.yaml
version: '3'
services:
tf_serving:
image: bitnami/tensorflow-serving:2
volumes:
- ${PWD}/clothing-model:/bitnami/model-data/1
ports:
- 8500:8500
- 8501:8501
environment:
- TENSORFLOW_SERVING_MODEL_NAME=clothing-model
And run it with
docker compose up
Added by Alex Litvinov

answer_llm:
If HPA doesn’t show CPU metrics, you should follow the provided solution:
- Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
- Run: kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
- Recreate the HPA. This should resolve the CPU metrics reporting issue.
answer_orig:
Problem: CPU metrics Shows Unknown
NAME         REFERENCE           TARGETS         MINPODS   MAXPODS   REPLICAS   AGE
credit-hpa   Deployment/credit   <unknown>/20%   1         3         1          18s
FailedGetResourceMetric       2m15s (x169 over 44m)  horizontal-pod-autoscaler  failed to get cpu utilization: unable to get metrics for resource cpu: unable to fetch metrics from resource metrics API:
Solution:
-> Delete HPA (kubectl delete hpa credit-hpa)
-> kubectl apply -f https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pythianarora/total-practice/master/sample-kubernetes-code/metrics-server.yaml
-> Create HPA
This should solve the cpu metrics report issue.
Added by Priya V

answer_llm: If you encounter errors with Istio during KServe installation because Istio is failing to update resources and you are on kubectl version > 1.25.0, you can resolve this by editing the file "quick_install.bash" after downloading it without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website and then run the bash script.
answer_orig:
Problem description:
Running this:
curl -s "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/kserve/kserve/release-0.9/hack/quick_install.sh" | bash
Fails with errors because of istio failing to update resources, and you are on kubectl > 1.25.0.
Check kubectl version with kubectl version
Solution description
Edit the file “quick_install.bash” by downloading it with curl without running bash. Edit the versions of Istio and Knative as per the matrix on the KServe website.
Run the bash script now.
Added by Andrew Katoch

question: What are the components found in a problem description?

answer_llm:
The solution description for the projects includes the following tasks:
- Think of a problem that's interesting for you and find a dataset for that
- Describe this problem and explain how a model could be used
- Prepare the data and doing EDA, analyze important features
- Train multiple models, tune their performance and select the best model
- Export the notebook into a script
- Put your model into a web service and deploy it locally with Docker
- Bonus points for deploying the service to the cloud.

Problem description
Solution description
(optional) Added by Name

question: Are the capstone and midterm assignments solo endeavors?

answer_llm: Based on the context provided, a midterm project should generally cover modules up to module-06. However, students can include anything extra that they want to feature in their project. It is important to document anything not covered in class. The project should also follow the guidelines provided such as finding a problem of interest, finding a dataset, describing the problem, preparing the data, training multiple models, deploying the model, and more. The project is meant to be a solo project, not a collaborative or group work.
answer_orig:
Answer: Ideally midterms up to module-06, capstones include all modules in that cohort’s syllabus. But you can include anything extra that you want to feature. Just be sure to document anything not covered in class.
Also watch office hours from previous cohorts. Go to DTC youtube channel and click on Playlists and search for {course yyyy}. ML Zoomcamp was first launched in 2021.

answer_llm: To find the projects you need to review for the capstone, you will receive a g-sheet with links to submitted projects along with hashed emails. You can find your assigned peer projects for review by searching for 3 identical entries in the spreadsheet using the hash value of your email address. The evaluation deadline must be adhered to.
answer_orig:
I am not sure how the project evaluate assignment works? Where do I find this? I have access to all the capstone 2 project, perhaps, I can randomly pick any to review.
Answer:
The link provided for example (2023/Capstone link ): https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdgoepohpgbM4MWTAHWuXa6r3NXKnxKcg4NDOm0bElAdXdnnA/viewform contains a list of all submitted projects to be evaluated. More specific, you are to review 3 assigned peer projects. In the spreadsheet are 3 hash values of your assigned peer projects. However, you need to derive the your hash value of your email address and find the value on the spreadsheet under the (reviewer_hash) heading.
To calculate your hash value run the python code below:
from hashlib import sha1
def compute_hash(email):
return sha1(email.lower().encode('utf-8')).hexdigest()
# Example usage **** enter your email below (Example1@gmail.com)****
email = "Example1@gmail.com"
hashed_email = compute_hash(email)
print("Original Email:", email)
print("Hashed Email (SHA-1):", hashed_email)
Edit the above code to replace Example1@gmail.com as your email address
Store and run the above python code from your terminal. See below as the Hashed Email (SHA-1) value
You then go to the link: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/e/2PACX-1vR-7RRtq7AMx5OzI-tDbkzsbxNLm-NvFOP5OfJmhCek9oYcDx5jzxtZW2ZqWvBqc395UZpHBv1of9R1/pubhtml?gid=876309294&single=true
Lastly, copy the “Hashed Email (SHA-1): bd9770be022dede87419068aa1acd7a2ab441675” value and search for 3 identical entries. There you should see your peer project to be reviewed.
By Emmanuel Ayeni
question: How do I find the projects I need to review for the capstone?

answer_llm:
The specific steps you should follow to calculate your email hash for project evaluation are as follows:
1. Run the provided Python code to compute your email hash.
2. Go to the provided link containing a spreadsheet of submitted projects.
3. Search for 3 identical entries matching your hashed email value to find your assigned peer projects for review.
(By Emmanuel Ayeni)

answer_llm:
QUESTION: How can I avoid a pickle attribute error when using waitress with my Docker container?

ANSWER: Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py). This will resolve the issue of the pickle attribute error when using waitress with a Docker container.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD

This would ensure that the class is in the same namespace when the model is saved and when it is loaded.
answer_orig:
When running a docker container with waitress serving the app.py for making predictions, pickle will throw an error that can't get attribute <name_of_class> on module __main__.
This does not happen when Flask is used directly, i.e. not through waitress.
The problem is that the model uses a custom column transformer class, and when the model was saved, it was saved from the __main__ module (e.g. python train.py). Pickle will reference the class in the global namespace (top-level code): __main__.<custom_class>.
When using waitress, waitress will load the predict_app module and this will call pickle.load, that will try to find __main__.<custom_class> that does not exist.
Solution:
Put the class into a separate module and import it in both the script that saves the model (e.g. train.py) and the script that loads the model (e.g. predict.py)
Note: If Flask is used (no waitress) in predict.py, and predict.py has the definition of the class, When  it is run: python predict.py, it will work because the class is in the same namespace as the one used when the model was saved (__main__).
Detailed info: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules
Marcos MJD
question: How should I modify my scripts to avoid pickle errors when using waitress?

answer_llm: You can find more detailed information about fixing pickle attribute errors with multiple modules on this link: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/27732354/unable-to-load-files-using-pickle-and-multiple-modules.

answer_llm: Based on the provided contexts, if Bento fails to import the module 'service' with a 'No module named sklearn' error, the solution is to modify the packages list in the `bentofile.yaml` file to include scikit-learn instead of just sklearn. Adding scikit-learn to the packages list should resolve the issue.
answer_orig:
I was getting the below error message when I was trying to create docker image using bentoml
[bentoml-cli] `serve` failed: Failed loading Bento from directory /home/bentoml/bento: Failed to import module "service": No module named 'sklearn'
Solution description
The cause was because , in bentofile.yaml, I wrote sklearn instead of scikit-learn. Issue was fixed after I modified the packages list as below.
packages: # Additional pip packages required by the service
- xgboost
- scikit-learn
- pydantic
Asia Saeed

answer_llm: The potential cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML could be setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the BentoML model saving stage in train.py. This can result in each input being converted to a different sized sparse matrix, leading to inconsistency in batch sizes. To address this issue, the BentoML model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during the saving of the BentoML model in train.py.
answer_orig:
You might see a long error message with something about sparse matrices, and in the swagger UI, you get a code 500 error with “” (empty string) as output.
Potential reason: Setting DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then storing this in a pipeline or custom object in the benotml model saving stage in train.py. This means that when the custom object is called in service.py, it will convert each input to a different sized sparse matrix, and this can't be batched due to inconsistent length. In this case, bentoml model signatures should have batchable set to False for production during saving the bentoml mode in train.py.
(Memoona Tahira)
question: What might be the cause of a long error message with something about sparse matrices and a code 500 error with an empty string output in BentoML?

answer_llm: In BentoML production, you may get different sized sparse matrices when using DictVectorizer or OHE during training if you set DictVectorizer or OHE to sparse while training, and then store this in a pipeline or custom object in the BentoML model saving stage in train.py. This can result in each input being converted to a different sized sparse matrix, leading to inconsistent lengths that can't be batched. The batchable should be set to False for production when saving the BentoML model in train.py to address this issue.

answer_llm: If your model is too big for GitHub, one solution is to compress the model using joblib. This can be done by using joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6), which will use zlib to compress the model. Just note that this compression process may take a few moments as the model is being compressed.
answer_orig:
If your model is too big for github one option is to try and compress the model using joblib. For example joblib.dump(model, model_filename, compress=('zlib', 6) will use zlib to compress the model. Just note this could take a few moments as the model is being compressed.
Quinn Avila

answer_llm: To resolve the unauthorized message when pushing a Docker image to Google Container Registry, you need to configure Docker with gcloud by typing the command "gcloud auth configure-docker" on the console after installing the Google Cloud SDK.
answer_orig:
When you try to push the docker image to Google Container Registry and get this message “unauthorized: You don't have the needed permissions to perform this operation, and you may have invalid credentials.”, type this below on console, but first install https://cloud.google.com/sdk/docs/install, this is to be able to use gcloud in console:
gcloud auth configure-docker
(Jesus Acuña)
question: What should I do if I get an unauthorized message when pushing a Docker image to Google Container Registry?

answer_llm:
To configure your console to push Docker images to Google Container Registry, you need to type the following command in your console after installing the Google Cloud SDK:
gcloud auth configure-docker
This will allow you to use gcloud in the console and push the Docker images to Google Container Registry.

answer_llm: To install tflite_runtime in a pipenv environment successfully, you should ensure that you are using Python 3.9 instead of Python 3.10. Tflite_runtime is not compatible with Python 3.10. After installing Python 3.9, you can try installing tflite_runtime again in your pipenv environment. If you are still facing issues, you can explore alternative options provided in the lecture materials, such as installing tflite_runtime from a specific wheel file or using the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development.
answer_orig:
I am getting this error message when I tried to install tflite in a pipenv environment
Error:  An error occurred while installing tflite_runtime!
Error text:
ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement tflite_runtime (from versions: none)
ERROR: No matching distribution found for tflite_runtime
This version of tflite do not run on python 3.10, the way we can make it work is by install python 3.9, after that it would install the tflite_runtime without problem.
Pastor Soto
Check all available versions here:
https://google-coral.github.io/py-repo/tflite-runtime/
If you don’t find a combination matching your setup, try out the options at
https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/tree/main/tflite
which you can install as shown in the lecture, e.g.
pip install https://github.com/alexeygrigorev/tflite-aws-lambda/raw/main/tflite/tflite_runtime-2.7.0-cp38-cp38-linux_x86_64.whl
Finally, if nothing works, use the TFLite included in TensorFlow for local development, and use Docker for testing Lambda.
Rileen Sinha (based on discussions on Slack)

answer_llm:
Based on the provided contexts, here is the answer to the question:

QUESTION: Where does pipenv create environments and how does it name them?

ANSWER: Pipenv creates environments in different locations depending on the operating system:
- OSX/Linux: ~/.local/share/virtualenvs/folder-name_cyrptic-hash
- Windows: C:\Users\<USERNAME>\.virtualenvs\folder-name_cyrptic-hash
The environment name is derived from the last folder in the folder directory where the pipenv command was used. The libraries of the environment are installed within this folder, and to activate the environment, you need to navigate back to the project folder and run `pipenv shell`. The location of the project folder serves as an identifier for the environment, instead of a specific name.
answer_orig:
Problem: If you run pipenv install and get this message. Maybe manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock.
Solution: Run: ` pipenv lock` for fix this problem and dependency files
Alejandro Aponte
question: What should I do if I see [pipenv.exceptions.ResolutionFailure] while running pipenv install?

answer_llm: The error you are encountering with Python_version and Python_full_version after running pipenv install can be fixed by opening the Pipfile in a nano editor and removing either the python_version or python_full_version line. After saving the changes, run `pipenv lock` to create the Pipfile.lock.
answer_orig:

Alejandro Aponte
question: Why might my dependencies not resolve when using pipenv?

answer_llm:
To manually change Pipfile and Pipfile.lock to resolve dependency issues, you can follow these steps:

1. Create a virtual environment using the Cmd command and use the pip freeze command to write the requirements in the text file.
2. If you encounter an error during the installation of Pipfile inside a Docker container, run the command `pipenv install --system --deploy --ignore-pipfile`.
3. If you receive a resolution failure warning indicating a mismatch in sub-dependencies, run `pipenv lock` to fix the problem with the dependency files.
4. In case your Pipfile.lock is out of date during a Docker build, you can either delete the Pipfile.lock and rebuild it with `pipenv lock`, or remove the pipenv environment along with Pipfile and Pipfile.lock before creating a new one.
5. If you encounter an error related to Python_version and Python_full_version after running `pipenv install`, edit the Pipfile file in a text editor to remove either the python_version or python_full_version line, then run `pipenv lock` to update the Pipfile.lock.

answer_llm: The `get_feature_names()` function is deprecated and will be removed in future versions. Instead, you should use the `get_feature_names_out()` method from the DictVectorizer function to access the feature names.
answer_orig:
Problem: In the course this function worked to get the features from the dictVectorizer instance: dv.get_feature_names(). But in my computer did not work. I think it has to do with library versions and but apparently that function will be deprecated soon:
Old: https://scikit-learn.org/0.22/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
New: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.html#sklearn.feature_extraction.text.CountVectorizer.get_feature_names
Solution: change the line dv.get_feature_names() to list(dv.get_feature_names_out))
Ibai Irastorza
question: Why doesn't dv.get_feature_names() work on my computer?

answer_llm: Yes, library versions could affect the dv.get_feature_names() function. The function is deprecated in version 1.0 and will be removed in version 1.2. It is recommended to use the method ".get_feature_names_out()" from DictVectorizer function instead to avoid any warnings.
